awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Chronology and Ecology of Late Pleistocene Megafauna at Rancho La Brea
awd_abstract_narration:
The Rancho La Brea tar pits of Los Angeles, California contain thousands of bones from large mammals --dire wolves, sabertooth cats, coyotes, extinct bison, horses, and others-- trapped in sticky surface oil deposits during the last Ice Age. This unparalleled fossil assemblage allows rigorous studies of extinct mammal biology, especially of carnivores which are rare at most fossil sites. The La Brea fossils span a critical time in Earth's history (approximately 50,000 years ago to the present) that includes major events such as the end of the last Ice Age, the arrival of humans in North America, and an extinction that killed two thirds of the large mammals on the continent. This unique deposit will be used to investigate relationships between major environmental changes and evolutionary variation (size, diet, etc.) in large mammals, information that is critical for promoting the survival of wildlife today. The project involves significant community outreach in the greater Los Angeles area through the Tar Pits Museum and will create educational content that will be available online for high school teachers across the country.

	The major impediment to system-level study at Rancho La Brea is a paucity of radiocarbon dates and the resulting inability to correlate biotic change with time. This project will intensively radiocarbon date samples from multiple pits spanning the last 50,000 years to establish the first detailed chronology for the entrapment of four extinct species of large mammals, and one extant species. It will involve the collection and compilation of census data for these species to track changes in total abundance and diversity, as well as data on morphological and dietary changes. A well-resolved chronology will allow these data on evolutionary changes in mammals and the Pleistocene megafaunal extinctions to be linked to existing records of major paleo-environmental changes. This work will have broad implications for our understanding of extinctions, survival, environmental variables, and humans on mammalian ecology, which is directly relevant to modern conservation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.inst_name: Los Angeles County Museum of Natural History Foundation
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: LOS ANGELES COUNTY MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY FOUNDATION

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: La Brea Tar Pits and Museum

por.por_cntn:
The La Brea Tar Pits paleontological locality in California, USA, comprises the world?s largest collection of Ice Age plants and animals.  This collection spans the last 60,000 years of Earth?s history, a time that includes major climate fluctuations, the arrival of humans on the American continent, and the extinction of most of the world?s large mammals. However, a lack of chronological control in the >130 viscous deposits has hindered scientists? ability to understand the relationship between these various phenomena and changes in the La Brea ecosystem.

This project sought to accomplish two main goals:  1) To develop a high-resolution chronology for several of the La Brea asphalt seeps, in order to facilitate research on these unique paleontological resources, and 2) to understand how large mammals (?megafauna?) at La Brea responded to late Pleistocene environmental changes. 

We radiocarbon dated more than 400 jaw bones from 5 species of La Brea megafauna: sabertoothed cats, dire wolves, extinct horses, extinct bison, and coyotes.  We dated only jaw bones to ensure that we were dating 400 different animals, and also so that individual dates could be compared with data we collected on tooth wear, bone and tooth chemistry, and shape and size of the jaws and teeth. 

We were able to constrain the ages of five ?tar pit? deposits spanning the last 40,000 years at La Brea, which will significantly expand researchers? ability to reconstruct past ecosystems in this region and trace their evolution through time. 

We have found changes in megafaunal diet and body size through time, as well as changes in the composition of the ecological community across periods of late-Pleistocene climate change.  Most notably, we were able to pinpoint the timing of local extinction of several megafaunal species in southern California, and align these disappearances with changes in the climate, the regional plant community, and North American human populations.  This discovery represents a major advance in research on the Ice Age megafaunal extinction event, and in scientists? understanding of how climate change and human actions can intersect to drive ecosystems to ecological tipping points.

Nearly all of the data we used in our research was collected in partnership with paid undergraduate interns, who were trained in all aspects of specimen-based research, and led some of the project research themselves.  Some student-led studies are in the process of publication in scientific journals, and many students had the opportunity to travel and present their research at national scientific conferences.   The interns were also trained in science communication and gave daily public presentations to museum visitors at La Brea Tar Pits during the summer months. 

The results of our research have been (and will continue to be) shared widely with the general public through public lectures, media coverage, and exhibitions in the La Brea Tar Pits Museum.

 


Last Modified: 07/29/2023
Modified by: Emily Lindsey
